lexUnit.name: abound.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: exist in large numbers or amounts.

sentence.text: Mouth-watering thoughts of all the fish and vegetables that abounded in the Egyptian delta soon produce an irresistible craving .
Myths abound in the heroin community as to the meaning of ` notification " and ` registration " and it is generally assumed that all ` official " agencies are in league with one another .
Moneylenders have abounded in every society , and in recent years have achieved great importance in developed economies because of the stimulus that their services have given to trade .
Temperaments and egos abound in Hollywood .
Rumours abounded at the salon regarding the relationship between Alice and le Ma√Ætre all of which he vehemently denied whenever he heard the gossip .
Flat-top Ekos did abound at the bottom of the market , but they all ended up with a Dulux psychedelic front and a magnetic pickup across the soundhole .
Disasters Abound At Southerness
He said : ` Generosity , happiness and warmth abound in their presence -- I so appreciate their friendship , especially when my wife was ill with leukaemia . "
Double-stops abound in nearly all aspects of blues playing .
" In this neighbourhood Citizens abound , " was the optimistic message the LCS received from west Cornwall in 1796 .
Sources of information on fish populations abound .
Of course , critics of privatization in transport abounded .
Temples abound along the coast .
Butterflies abounded : we saw small copper , green hair streak , grizzled skipper , orange tip , painted lady , common blue , speckled wood , small heath , wall brown and red admiral .
Bowls clubs abound , and for the golfer there is a good selection of courses , ranging from parkland courses inland to some truly great links , particularly along the northern coast .
On the one hand , myths abounded about the non-addictive nature of heroin when ` chased " .
Rumours abounded of white slave traffic .
Historical precedents abound in Islam ‚Ä¶
Prawns abound in most locations , and small ones may comprise the majority of the catch .
Examples abound in the professions , for example the question of auditors and joint stock companies , or solicitors and conveyancing .
Bureaucracy abounds and continues to proliferate , nepotism is more rife , I am told , than under Franco , standards in almost everything leave so much to be desired .
Special software abounds , most of it costing less than ¬£30 .
Memories abound on the tee , of Lyle hitting his seven-iron from the fairway bunker to 10 ft , of Woosnam creaming his drive way to the left and almost redefining the way to play the hole .
In a city of such human proportions it is not surprising that parks and gardens abound for recreation and relaxation .
